en.topic_meaning: Section 14 of the Constitution not only guarantees everyone a general right to privacy but also provides protection against specific instances of privacy violations such as the right not to have one’s home searched, property seized and the right to the privacy of one’s communications. The protection of this right acknowledges that everyone has a right to personal autonomy and intimacy.
en.interpretation: The constitutional protection afforded to the right to privacy has been interpreted by the Constitutional Court to extend to aspects of a person’s life to which a “legitimate expectation of privacy” exists. On considering whether a violation of the right to privacy occurred, the courts will not only consider what the victim expects to be private (the subjective expectation) but also the objective component of the expectation of privacy, considering whether society would recognise the expectation as reasonable. The objective component focuses on a determination by a court on whether the person claiming that their privacy was infringed could reasonably expect their privacy to be protected in the particular circumstances.
en.mechanism: The protection afforded to the right to privacy becomes more intense the closer it relates to the intimate personal sphere of life, such as the home, and less intense as it moves away from that core. For example, if someone’s family life, sexual preference and home environment will be more fiercely protected by the right to privacy. The right to privacy is inter-related to the right to dignity.
en.legislation: The Protection of Personal Information Act 4 of 2013 was specifically enacted to give effect to the right to informational privacy and the Act provides strict measures for the processing of personal information by public and private bodies. The Information Regulator established in terms of the Act is an independent body empowered to monitor compliance of the Act.

en.title: Section 15: Freedom of Religion, Belief and Opinion
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 15(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the “right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion”. The right to religious freedom also extends to the right not to hold such beliefs. The drafters of the Constitution were conscious of providing equal treatment to all religions and to ensure constitutional protection to the right to freedom of thought and belief, which includes atheism and free thought.

Section 15(2) of the Constitution stipulates that religious observances may be held at State-aided institutions under certain conditions such as the need to ensure that attendance is in terms of rules made by a public authority, are conducted on an equitable basis and attendance is “free and voluntary”.
en.interpretation: This section is important as it emphasises that diverse beliefs and opinions are worthy of protection and should be accommodated, and acknowledges that South Africa is a multi-cultural society. The right to freedom of religion is protected if there is an absence of coercion or constraint on a religious belief or practice and the right would be infringed if measures were adopted which forced people to act in a manner which opposes their beliefs.
en.mechanism: Section 15 of the Constitution provides the right to believe in a particular God or Gods and the religious teachings associated with a belief in that God or Gods; the right to remain uncertain about believing in a God or Gods and the religious teachings associated with a belief in that God or Gods; as well as the right not to believe in any God at all. However, it is not only the right to believe or not to believe that is protected by section 15 of the Constitution. Section 15 also protects the right to act in accordance with those beliefs or non-beliefs and for a person to organise their life in a manner that demonstrates allegiance to the particular chosen belief system.
en.legislation: Section 15(3) of the Constitution empowers the State to enact legislation to recognise customary and religious marriages and the Recognition of Customary Marriages Act 120 of 1998 affords legal recognition to customary marriages prescribing to certain requirements and provides equal status to spouses in customary marriages.

en.title: Section 16: Freedom of Expression
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to freedom of expression encompassing freedom of the press, freedom to receive or impart information, freedom of artistic creativity and academic and scientific freedom.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 16(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of expression which not only encompasses freedom of the press and other media, but also includes “freedom to receive or impart information or ideas”, “freedom of artistic creativity” and academic and scientific freedom.

Section 16(2) of the Constitution specifically explains what forms of expression are not constitutionally protected and that the right to freedom of expression does not extend to these categories of expression. This subsection provides an internal limitation on the right. These limited categories include “propaganda for war”; the “incitement of imminent violence” or “advocacy of hatred that is based on race, ethnicity, gender or religion and that constitutes incitement to cause harm”. The last category is colloquially known as the hate speech prohibition. These categories exist because they have the potential to negatively affect the dignity of others and cause harm.
en.mechanism: It is important to note that if a form of expression falls into one of the limited categories in terms of section 16(2) of the Constitution, it is not protected by the Constitution and the question whether it limits the right to freedom of expression does not arise since these forms of speech are prohibited by the Constitution and fall outside the bounds of constitutionally protected speech. However, if the form of expression does not fall into one of these limited categories it is in fact an expression protected by the Constitution and any laws attempting to regulate and/or limit such expression must satisfy the limitation of rights test in terms of section 36 of the Constitution.
en.legislation: The Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act 4 of 2000, is the constitutionally mandated legislation envisaged in section 9(4) of the Constitution and amongst other things, regulates hate speech.

en.title: Section 17: Assembly, Demonstration, Picket and Petition
en.snippet: Protects the right to assemble, to demonstrate, to picket and to present petitions on the condition that they are held “peacefully and unarmed”.
en.topic_meaning: Section 17 of the Constitution protects the right to assemble, to demonstrate, to picket and to present petitions on the condition that they are held “peacefully and unarmed”. Protests and assemblies provided a powerful mechanism in the struggle against apartheid and the constitutional protection of this right must be viewed in this historical context. The right is also an important form of engagement in a democratic society, providing a political tool for marginalised groups who would have no other means to voice their grievances.
en.interpretation: Assemblies, demonstrations, pickets and petitions allow groups, whose influence on political parties or the political process would otherwise be minimal, to raise issues that are important to them, to draw attention to these issues and to engage with their fellow citizens and representatives about these issues.
en.legislation: The Regulations of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993 provides detail on the lawful conduct of gatherings. This piece of legislation pre-dates the Constitution and faced a constitutional challenge in 2018. The Constitutional Court declared section 12(1)(a) of the Act, which criminalised the failure to notify the relevant authority of a gathering, unconstitutional and invalid.

en.title: Section 18: Freedom of Association
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to freedom of association.
en.topic_meaning: Section 18 of the Constitution guarantees “everyone the right to freedom of association”. The right has been described as a correlative right as it reinforces other rights in the Bill of Rights. For instance, the right reinforces an individual’s right to form a political party and reinforces a worker’s right to form and join a trade union. The right protects the choice of individuals and limits state interference. This right provides individuals with autonomy and enables people to make choices about how they wish to arrange their lives and establish their identities as people in relationships with others in a given society, thus advancing respect for and protecting diversity.
en.interpretation: It is important to emphasise that the right to freedom of association also extends to the right not to be forced to associate. This negative aspect of the right to freedom of association played a critical role in the Constitutional Court’s finding in New Nation Movement NPC and Others v President of South Africa and Others [2020] ZACC 11 that the Electoral Act 73 of 1998 was unconstitutional to the extent that it prohibited an independent candidate to contest national and provincial elections.
en.mechanism: Even though the right has a communal aspect, it is primarily a right that belongs to the individual rather than any association that has been established to give better effect to the protection of the rights of the individual.

en.title: Section 19: Political Rights
en.snippet: Stipulates broad political rights such as the right to form a political party, the right to campaign for a political party and to participate in free, fair and regular elections and to stand for public office if so elected.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 19 of the Constitution stipulates broad political rights such as the right to form a political party, the right to “campaign for a political party or cause” and it guarantees the right of every citizen to participate in “free, fair and regular elections” and to stand for public office, and if elected, to hold office.

Section 19 of the Constitution, read with section 1(d) of the Constitution, highlights the principle that an integral aspect of representative democracy is that it is a multiparty democracy rather than a one-party state that places limits on political participation at a political level.
en.interpretation: The broad spectrum of political rights guaranteed in the Constitution must be viewed in its historical context where the majority of South African citizens were denied the right to participate in politics.
en.legislation: The Electoral Act 73 of 1998 regulates elections of the National Assembly, the Provincial Legislature and Municipal councils. In 2020, the Constitutional Court found that the Electoral Act was unconstitutional to the extent that independent candidates were not able to be elected for the National Assembly and Provincial Legislature, and Parliament was required to remedy this defect.

en.title: Section 20: Citizenship
en.snippet: Stipulates that no citizen may be deprived of citizenship.
en.topic_meaning: Section 20 of the Constitution stipulates that “no citizen may be deprived of citizenship”. This right can be described as a right which protects people against statelessness and affirms that everyone ought to be a citizen of a country. It is aligned with South Africa’s international law commitments not to deprive a citizen arbitrarily of their citizenship and to provide protection against statelessness, which can have grave consequences.
en.interpretation: The Constitutional Court has held that citizenship is directly interlinked with the right to dignity and is much more than a legal status as it is central to a person’s identity.
en.mechanism: The South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 provides the manner for acquisition for South African citizenship and chapter 3 of the Act deals specifically with the loss of citizenship.

en.title: Section 21: Freedom of Movement and Residence
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to freedom of movement and residence and stipulates that every citizen has the right to enter, remain and reside anywhere in the Republic.
en.topic_meaning: Section 21 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of movement and residence and stipulates that not only does every citizen have “the right to enter, remain and reside anywhere in the Republic” but everyone also has the right to move freely and to leave the Republic. Furthermore, in terms of this section every citizen also has the right to a passport.
en.interpretation: The right has to be viewed in light of the historical context that apartheid laws imposed great restrictions on the free movement of Black people in the country and that the constitutional recognition of the right of people to move freely and for citizens to acquire a passport is a clear break-away from the authoritarian rule of the apartheid government. It is important to note that the right to freely move and leave the Republic is afforded to everyone while the right to enter, remain, reside and the right to a passport is only afforded to citizens.

en.title: Section 22: Freedom of Trade, Occupation and Profession
en.snippet: Guarantees South African citizens the right to choose their trade, occupation or profession freely.
en.topic_meaning: Section 22 of the Constitution guarantees South African citizens the right to “choose their trade, occupation or profession freely”. It furthermore stipulates that the “practice of a trade, occupation or profession may be regulated by law”.
en.interpretation: It is important to note that this constitutional right is restricted to citizens only. It is phrased as a negative right, limiting interference from the State in a person’s choice of trade, occupation or profession. The right to dignity is also directly interlinked with the freedom to choose a trade, occupation and profession. The constitutional recognition of this right must also be seen in historical context where racist laws of the apartheid Government resulted in economic exclusion.
en.mechanism: Although the State is prohibited from interfering in a citizen’s right to choose a trade, occupation or profession, the State is allowed to regulate a trade, occupation or profession - as is the case with the medical profession for instance – but it must be regulated in terms of legislation.

en.title: Section 23: Labour Relations
en.snippet: Deals with the rights that people have at work.
en.topic_meaning: Section 23(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the “right to fair labour practices”. Section 23(2) of the Constitution stipulates various specific rights that a worker has, such as the right to “form and join a trade union” and to strike. Section 23(3) guarantees certain rights to employers such as the right to “form and join an employer’s organisation”. The rights of trade unions and employers’ organisations are stipulated in section 23(4) and section 23(5)> provides that trade unions, employers’ organisations and employers have the right to engage in collective bargaining and that national legislation may be enacted to regulate collective bargaining.
en.interpretation: While most terms under section 23, such as “employers” or “trade unions”, are easily definable, the courts have often had to provide a definition for the term “worker”.
en.legislation: The Labour Relations Act 66 of 1995 was specifically enacted to give effect and regulate this constitutional right. It is the national legislation referred to in sections 23(5) and (6) of the Constitution. The Act provides a framework for collective bargaining, the resolution of labour disputes and the regulation of organisational rights of trade unions. It is important to note that the Labour Relations Act does not apply to members of the National Defence Force or to members of the State Security Agency.

en.title: Section 24: Environment
en.snippet: Guarantees the right to an environment that is not harmful to their health or well-being.
en.topic_meaning: Section 24 of the Constitution confirms that everyone has a right to an environment that is not “harmful to their health or well-being” and places a positive obligation on the State to protect the environment for the benefit of future and present generations. The State is obliged to enact legislation and take other reasonable measures to ensure it fulfils this duty and if the State fails to do so, an individual can rely on section 24 of the Constitution. This constitutional obligation applies not only to the State but also to action taken by companies and individuals. An important addition in the Final Constitution was ensuring that the State secures ecological sustainable developments and the use of natural resources, as required by section 24(b)(iii) of the Constitution.
en.legislation: The National Environment Management Act 107 of 1998, gives effect to section 24 of the Constitution and provides an integrated environmental management framework.

en.title: Section 25: Property Rights
en.snippet: The property provision in the Bill of Rights has both protecting and reformative provisions.
en.topic_meaning: Section 25(1) to (3) of the Constitution provides protection against arbitrary deprivation of property and stipulates the requirements for expropriation. This means that the State cannot interfere with someone’s property except in terms of a law of general application for a public purpose or in the public interest and subject to compensation. Section 25(4) to (9) of the Constitution can be described as the “reformative provisions” and they oblige the State to take action to promote land and other reforms to ensure equitable access to South Africa’s natural resources.
en.interpretation: Section 25 of the Constitution, the property clause, balances competing interests. On the one hand, the right protects the holders of existing property rights and on the other hand, the section also aims to correct historical injustices concerning land and property rights, which were often non-existent or tenuous under apartheid. No one may be deprived of property except in terms of a law of general application.
en.legislation: In December 2019, the Ad Hoc Committee on the Amendment of Section 25 of the Constitution published the Constitution Eighteenth Amendment Bill. The Bill aimed to amend section 25 of the Constitution to provide that where land and any other improvements are expropriated for the purpose of land reform, the amount of compensation may be nil. It is important to note, that as the Bill relates to an amendment of a right in the Bill of Rights, such an amendment can only be passed with a supporting vote of at least two thirds of the members in the National Assembly and a supporting vote of at least six provinces in the National Council of Provinces.

en.title: Section 26: Housing
en.snippet: Guarantees the right to have access to housing and not be evicted without court order.
en.topic_meaning: Section 26(1) of the Constitution provides that everyone has “the right to have access to adequate housing” and section 26(2) obliges the State to take “reasonable legislative and other measures, within its available resources, to achieve the progressive realisation of this right”. Section 26(3) of the Constitution confirms that no person may be evicted from their home or have their home demolished without a court order, after the Court has considered “all the relevant circumstances”.
en.interpretation:
Section 26(1) of the Constitution places a positive obligation on the State to provide housing. This section specifically refers to “access to” which has been interpreted to mean that the right to adequate housing means more than just providing bricks and mortar but that necessary services must be made available, such as land, water and electricity. The State’s duty in fulfilling this obligation will differ depending on the economic group. For a more affluent economic sector it may mean securing the provision of electricity and water whereas for a less affluent group it may mean making land available to build houses in addition to providing these services.

Section 26(2) refers to the obligation of the State to ensure 'progressive realisation' of this right. This is a limitation that recognises that socio-economic rights cannot be given full effect immediately. But this subsection also imposes duties on the State. The State must actually take ' reasonable legislative and other measures' towards realising the rights. The State will need to show that the legislative and other measures applied to fulfil this right are reasonable: that it is using its available resources and taking active steps over time to fulfil this right. Thus, there is no set standard as to how many houses, for example, the State has to provide. The State just needs to show that it is acting within its abilities and within available resources.
en.legislation: Section 26(3) of the Constitution provides strong protection against undue State interference and the Prevention of Illegal Eviction from and Unlawful Occupation of Land Act 19 of 1998 specifically gives effect to section 26(3) and provides for the procedure for the eviction of unlawful occupiers.

en.title: Section 27: Healthcare, Food, Water and Security
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to have access to health care services.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 27(1) of the Constitution essentially guarantees everyone the right to have “access to health care services including reproductive health care, sufficient food and water and social security, including, if they are unable to support themselves and their dependants, appropriate social assistance”.

In terms of section 27(2) of the Constitution, the State “must take reasonable legislative and other measures, within its available resources, to achieve the progressive realisation of these rights”.

Lastly section 27(3) of the Constitution relates to the right that “no one may be refused emergency medical treatment”.
en.interpretation: Section 27 of the Constitution forms part of the group of socio-economic rights in the Constitution. Socio-economic rights place a positive obligation on the State to take action to ensure the fulfilment of basic societal needs.
en.mechanism:
Section 27 of the Constitution forms part of the group of socio-economic rights in the Constitution. Socio-economic rights place a positive obligation on the State to take action to ensure the fulfilment of basic societal needs.

The fulfilment of access to these socio-economic rights are regulated in three ways. The first way relates to the reasonableness of the measures adopted by the State; the second relates to the use of resources and available budget and lastly the State must show that it is making progress towards the fulfilment of these rights – it has to show what steps it has taken to fulfil these rights over time.

A distinction is made in relation to the right to emergency medical treatment and the right to access to healthcare services. The right to emergency medical treatment relates essentially to the right not to be denied an ambulance in an emergency situation or to be turned away from a hospital to receive immediate and necessary medical care.

en.title: Section 28: Children
en.snippet: Provides a range of rights to children, extending from the right to legal identity to the right to parental care.
en.topic_meaning: Section 28 of the Constitution provides a range of rights to children: from the right to legal identity; the constitutional protection of a child’s right “to a name and a nationality from birth”; to the right to parental care; and the right to be protected from “exploitative labour practices”.
en.interpretation: It is important to note that the constitutional rights extended to children in terms of section 28 of the Constitution is in addition to any other constitutional rights that children are entitled to in the Bill of Rights. The purpose of section 28 of the Constitution is specifically to protect children in vulnerable situations.
en.mechanism: The requirement of the “best interests of the child” standard has been cemented in the Constitution and section 28(2) of the Constitution emphasises that “a child’s best interests are of paramount importance in every matter concerning the child”. This standard provides that, for example, in a legal dispute concerning children, the Court must focus on what would be best for the child in the circumstances before focusing on the rights and preferences of the parents. The “best interests” standard also obliges the State to take action to ensure the necessary legal and administrative structures are in place to protect children.
en.legislation: The Children’s Act 38 of 2005 has been enacted specifically to give effect to the rights of children.

en.title: Section 29: Education
en.snippet: Provides that everyone has the right to basic education and to further education, which the state, through reasonable measures, must make progressively available and accessible.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 29 of the Constitution provides for education rights and it stipulates that everyone has the right to basic education and to “further education, which the state, through reasonable measures, must make progressively available and accessible”.

Section 29(2) also provides that everyone has the right to receive education in any official language of their choice, where this is reasonably practicable. This is an important inclusion because during the apartheid era, only English and Afrikaans were recognised as official languages and mediums of instruction. This right is, however, restricted by internal limitations and has been the subject of many legal disputes.

Lastly, section 29(3) of the Constitution provides protection for the right to establish independent schools subject to such schools:

i) not discriminating on the basis of race;

ii) registering with the State and;

iii) maintaining appropriate standards.

Importantly, the State is not obliged to make available resources to such schools as they operate at their own expense and the State only has a negative duty not to interfere with such schools.
en.interpretation:
Unlike other socio-economic rights in the Bill of Rights, the right to basic education is an absolute right and is not subject to resource constraints. With the right to “further education”, the State is not obliged to provide access to everyone immediately. The State is only obliged to take reasonable measures over time to provide access to such institutions.

As the right to basic education extends to “everyone”, it is not only restricted to citizens and applies to non-citizens as well. Furthermore, the right to basic education is not only restricted to accessing available places at schools, but also includes accessing teaching materials and ensuring that facilities are appropriate for learning.

en.title: Section 30: Language and Culture
en.snippet: Affords protection to the right to use one’s own language and to participate in the cultural life of one’s choice.
en.topic_meaning: Section 30 of the Constitution protects the right to use one’s own language and to participate in the cultural life of one’s choice. It is one of various provisions in the Constitution affording protection to ethnic, religious and linguistic groups in South Africa and also reflects international law commitments to provide protection to such groups.
en.mechanism: It is, however, subject to the condition that these rights may not be exercised in a way that is inconsistent with other fundamental human rights guaranteed in the Bill of Rights. For instance, the right to exercise a cultural practice must be consistent with an individual’s right to dignity and freedom and security of the person. If the right is practised in a manner that endangers a person’s life then it is inconsistent with the constitutional protection afforded in terms of section 30 of the Constitution and the State can intervene to protect an individual.

en.title: Section 31: Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities
en.snippet: Affords protection to persons belonging in different cultural, religious or linguistic communities.
en.topic_meaning: Section 31 of the Constitution affords protection to cultural, religious and linguistic communities. Persons belonging to such groups may not be denied the right “to enjoy their culture, practise their religion and use their language”. The State may not interfere with the rights of persons belonging to such groups “to form and maintain cultural, religious and linguistic associations”.
en.interpretation: Section 31 of the Constitution protects both the religious, cultural and linguistic interests of an individual and that of a community. For an individual to claim the rights in terms of this section, the individual needs to prove that there is a link between them and the specific group. Section 31 of the Constitution is also specifically based on article 27 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and therefore the constitutional protection afforded to cultural, religious and linguistic communities is aligned with international law.
en.mechanism: These rights may not be exercised in a manner inconsistent with any other provisions contained in the Bill of Rights. For instance, if a religious practice by a community harms an individual’s life, then section 31 of the Constitution cannot outweigh an individual’s right to freedom and security of person if this right is endangered. People may not exercise these rights in a way that unjustifiably limits the rights of others.

en.title: Section 32: Access to Information
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to access to any information held by the State and any information held by another person that is required for the exercise or protection of any rights.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 32 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to access “any information held by the State” as well as “any information held by another person and that is required for the exercise or protection of any rights”.

It is important that the guarantee of this constitutional right is a commitment to break away from the authoritarian regime of the apartheid government. Access to information is critical to ensuring that the constitutional values of accountability, transparency and openness are realised and it is a powerful tool to utilise in combatting corruption. The right of access to information is based, in part, on the principle that an individual should be allowed to access information that is specifically about them, or in a more general sense, information that the State uses to make decisions that may affect an individual or the public at large.
en.legislation: The State is furthermore obliged to enact national legislation to give effect to this constitutional right and the Promotion of Access to Information Act 2 of 2000 (PAIA) specifically gives effect to this right. A person who wishes to access information held by the State or a private institution will be required to follow the procedures set out in PAIA.

en.title: Section 33: Just Administrative Action
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to administrative action that is lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 33 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to “administrative action that is lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair” and provides individuals with the right to request reasons where their rights have been “adversely affected by administrative action”. This right ensures that the correct procedures are followed when making administrative decisions, and that such decisions are lawful and reasonable. The primary way in which this right is given effect is through judicial review of administrative action.

The enactment of the constitutional right to just administrative action reflects a deep commitment to limit wide powers given to the executive. The apartheid state was characterised by the exercise of unlimited power by the state. In contrast, under South Africa’s new constitutional order, such power will now have to comply with the Constitution and has to be “lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair”.
en.interpretation: Administrative action relates to the exercise of public power by organs of State and other public functionaries. It refers to the conduct of the bureaucracy in carrying out their daily functions which bears consequences for individuals or groups. It is distinct from executive action, that is, acts taken by members of the executive in the exercise of their powers, which often entails the implementation of legislation and the formulation of policy. Such acts are not reviewable as administrative action, but are still subject to judicial review on less exacting grounds of review.
en.legislation: The State is obliged to enact national legislation to give effect to section 33 of the Constitution and the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 2000 was enacted to give effect to these rights. Certain acts do not fall under “administrative action” and are not reviewable in terms of the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act. This includes judicial acts (such as presiding over cases) by the judiciary; acts by the President when exercising his inherent powers conferred by the Constitution, such as appointing commissions of inquiry or granting presidential pardons; acts by the legislature when exercising their primary functions; and purely political decisions by cabinet.

en.title: Section 34: Access to Courts
en.snippet: Guarantees everyone the right to have a legal dispute decided in a fair public hearing before a court or an appropriate forum.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 34 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right “to have any dispute that can be resolved by the application of law decided in a fair public hearing before a court or where appropriate by another independent and impartial tribunal or forum”.

This right is an essential component of the rule of law. This right is an important one in contrast to the ousting of the jurisdiction of courts which was allowed during the apartheid-era. This section creates a due process right which requires a public and fair hearing. However, any dispute brought before a court must be capable of being resolved by the application of law.
en.interpretation:
This constitutional right cannot be interpreted to mean that an individual can approach any court or independent tribunal to resolve a specific dispute as the rules of jurisdiction (that is, rules regulating which courts can hear which matter) still apply. However, an individual has the right to approach a competent court or tribunal where appropriate, to resolve the dispute and cannot be forced to give up this right.

The State bears an obligation to enhance access to justice through legislative and other measures.

en.title: Section 35: Arrested, Detained and Accused Persons
en.snippet: Provides for the rights of arrested, detained and accused persons.
en.topic_meaning:
The criminal justice system has been extensively revolutionised under South Africa’s new constitutional order and reflects strict checks and balances to ensure state power is not abused. Section 35 of the Constitution specifically provides for the rights of arrested, detained and accused persons and the range of constitutional rights in this section will only apply if a person falls into one of these categories.

Section 35(1)(a) of the Constitution for example specifically provides that a person arrested for allegedly committing an offence has the right “to remain silent” including various other rights such as the right “not to be compelled to make any confessions or admissions that could be used in evidence against that person”. Detained persons in terms of section 35(2) of the Constitution, which includes every sentenced person, has the right “to be informed promptly of the reason for being detained” and an accused person in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution has the right to a fair trial which includes various other rights such as the right “to be informed of the charge with sufficient detail to answer it” as well as the rights to be presumed innocent and not be compelled to give self-incriminating evidence.

Section 35(5) of the Constitution provides a remedy for breach of constitutional rights and stipulates that “evidence obtained in a manner that violates any right in the Bill of Rights” must be excluded if the “admission of that evidence would render the trial unfair or otherwise be detrimental to the administration of justice”.

en.title: Section 36: Limitations of Rights
en.snippet: Provides criteria for circumstances when rights enshrined in the Bill of Rights may be limited.
en.topic_meaning: Section 36 provides criteria for circumstances when rights enshrined in the Bill of Rights may be limited. Rights contained in the Bill of Rights are not absolute and may be limited. Such limitation must conform to the criteria set out in section 36 of the Constitution in order to be justifiable.
en.interpretation:
Section 36 of the Constitution applies to all rights in the Bill of Rights and entails a two-stage approach. A right in the Bill of Rights may only be limited in terms of a “law of general application”. A law of general application is a law which applies equally to the population at large and is not aimed at specific individuals only. The question to be asked is whether the limitation or infringement is contained in a law of general application (e.g. legislation or regulations). At this first stage one does not consider whether the limitation is justifiable, but it is only a question of whether there is a limitation at all.

If there is a limitation, then one will consider whether the limitation is “reasonable and justifiable in an open and democratic society based on human dignity, equality and freedom, taking into account all relevant factors” which includes “the nature of the right”; “the importance of the purpose of the limitation”; “the nature and extent of the limitation”; “the relation between the limitation and its purpose” and “less restrictive means to achieve the purpose”.

It is only after weighing up these factors and any other relevant factors that the Court will either find that the limitation is constitutionally justifiable or not. This entails a value judgment and a proportionality analysis, which requires a balancing of the various interests at play. Lastly, the burden of proof is on the party wishing to to justify the limitation. So, the legislature would need to show that there is a reason why a law regulating the content of films is justified in limiting the right to freedom of expression.
en.mechanism: For instance, a law that regulates the content of films and provides restrictions on access to such films, limits the right to freedom of expression. However, if the purpose of this restriction is to protect children from viewing harmful content, the question will arise whether this law restricting freedom of expression is a reasonable and justifiable limitation in terms of section 36 of the Constitution. If the law satisfies the criteria of section 36 of the Constitution then this limitation is constitutionally justifiable.

en.title: Section 37: States of Emergency
en.snippet: Provides when and under which circumstances a state of emergency may be declared.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 37 of the Constitution provides when and under which circumstances a state of emergency may be declared. The declaration of a state of emergency may only be made when certain strict conditions have been met in terms of this section. The temporary suspension of fundamental human rights is justified on the basis that the life of the nation is threatened by “war, invasion, general insurrection, disorder, natural disaster or other public emergency and the declaration is necessary to restore peace and order”.

The declaration of a state of emergency may only be done in terms of an Act of Parliament and may not last longer than 21 days unless the National Assembly resolves to extend this declaration and again, such extension depends on certain conditions being met.

This section also provides a “Table of Non-Derogable Rights” and any law enacted to give effect to a state of emergency may not derogate from these rights to the extent provided for in the table, and for some rights the right may not be derogated from at all. For instance, the right to life is non-derogable in its entirety.
en.legislation: It is also important to note that there is a difference between the declaration of a State of Emergency and the declaration of a State of National Disaster. The onslaught of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020 caused the declaration of a National State of Disaster in terms of the Disaster Management Act 57 of 2002 whereas a State of Emergency may only be declared under the State of Emergency Act 64 of 1997, and section 37 of the Constitution, and only in very limited circumstances.

en.title: Section 38: Enforcement of Rights
en.snippet: Relates to the enforcement of rights in the Bill of Rights in a court and sets out who can approach a court to allege that a right has been infringed.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 38 of the Constitution relates to the enforcement of rights in the Bill of Rights in a competent court and sets out who can approach a court to allege that their, or another person’s, rights have been infringed or threatened. This section adopts a wide approach to standing and “threatened” indicates that a person may also approach a court if they believe there might be a future violation of a right in the Bill of Rights.

Persons who may approach a Court include: “anyone acting in their own interest; anyone acting on behalf of another person who cannot act in their own name; anyone acting as a member of, or in the interest of, a group or class of persons; anyone acting in the public interest and an association acting in the interest of its members”. The Court in such an instance may “grant appropriate relief, including a declaration of rights”.
en.mechanism: In order to rely on section 38 of the Constitution, one does not need to prove that a right of a specific person or persons have been infringed or threatened – one only needs to allege that a right in the Bill of Rights has been infringed or threatened and provide support for this allegation.

en.title: Section 39: Interpretation of Bill of Rights
en.snippet: Provides guidance on the interpretation of the Bill of Rights.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 39 of the Constitution provides guidance on the interpretation of the Bill of Rights.

Section 39(1) of the Constitution obliges a court, tribunal or forum when interpreting the Bill of Rights to “promote the values that underlie an open and democratic society based on human dignity, equality and freedom” and obliges such a court, tribunal or forum to consider international law and states that it has a discretion to consider foreign law.

Section 39(2) of the Constitution also obliges any court, tribunal or forum on “interpretation of any legislation, and when developing the common law or customary law to “promote the spirit, purport and objects of the Bill of Rights”. Section 39(2) governs indirect application of the Bill of Rights and allows for the common law to be developed in accordance with the Bill of Rights. When using section 39(2), courts rely on the values that underpin the Bill of Rights and consider whether the law requires to be developed in order to conform to these constitutional values.

Section 39(3) of the Constitution provides that the Bill of Rights does not deny the existence of any rights or freedoms contained in the common law, customary law or legislation but again only to the extent that it is consistent with the Bill of Rights.
en.interpretation: The use of international law relates to both binding and non-binding international law for interpretative guidance. For instance, South Africa signed and ratified (thus agreeing that it applies to South African law) the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, providing interpretative guidance on various civil and political rights. If someone alleges that a specific law infringes on their constitutional right to privacy of communication the Court is obliged to consider the ICCPR’s guidance on the matter. Regarding the use of foreign law for interpretative guidance, there is a discretion on a court, tribunal or forum to refer to such case law and one always has to be cautious of the fact that a judicial system may differ and any comparison must take this into account.

en.title: Co-operative Government and Intergovernmental Relations
en.snippet: Governs the constitutional relationship between the three spheres of government.
en.topic_meaning: Chapter 3 of the Constitution governs the constitutional relationship between the three spheres of government and stipulates the principles of co-operative governance between national, provincial and local government. Importantly section 40(1) of the Constitution confirms that each of these three spheres of government is “distinctive, interdependent and interrelated”. This confirmation recognises the independence of each sphere to govern within its sphere but at the same time recognises the need for interdependency.
en.mechanism: Section 41 of the Constitution obliges all three spheres of government and organs of state within each sphere to adhere to stipulated constitutional principles such as the need to “preserve the peace, national unity and the indivisibility of the Republic” and the need to “co-operate with one another in mutual trust and good faith by assisting and supporting one another”.
en.legislation: Section 42 of the Constitution requires the enactment of legislation giving effect to these intergovernmental relations and procedures for the settlement of intergovernmental disputes. The Intergovernmental Relations Framework Act 13 of 2005 specifically provides the framework governing the relationship between these three spheres of government.

en.title: President and National Executive
en.snippet: Provides for the power and functions of the President and the National Executive as well as the election and removal of the President by way of impeachment or a motion of no confidence.
en.topic_meaning:
Chapter 5 of the Constitution provides for the powers and functions of the President and the National Executive as well as the election and removal of the President by way of impeachment or a motion of no confidence. The requirements for a motion of no confidence in the Cabinet, excluding the President is also covered in section 102.

Importantly, sections 84 and 85 of the Constitution provides for the exclusive powers of the President as head of State and head of the national executive respectively. The powers of the President as head of State include the power to assent to and sign Bills and to pardon or reprieve any offenders. These are original presidential powers which may only be exercised by the President.
en.interpretation: Section 85 of the Constitution confirms that the executive authority of the Republic is vested in the President who, together with members of the cabinet, must implement national legislation, co-ordinate functions of state departments and develop and implement national policy. This section refers to the President’s powers as head of the national executive.
en.legislation: The exercise of executive power of the National Executive does not constitute “administrative action” in terms of the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 2000 and therefore cannot be reviewed in terms of this Act. This, however, does not mean the exercise of these powers cannot be reviewed by the Courts. The Courts will review the exercise of this power under the principle of legality enshrined in section 1(c) of the Constitution.

en.title: Provincial Executive Authority
en.snippet: Provides for the powers and functions of the Premier and what can be done when a municipality does not adhere to its executive duties.
en.topic_meaning:
Sections 125 to 141 of the Constitution, under Chapter 6 of the Constitution, deals with provincial executives.

Section 125 of the Constitution confirms that the executive authority of the province is vested in the Premier and the Premier together with other members of the executive Council exercises the executive authority which includes “implementing provincial legislation”; “developing and implementing provincial policy” and “co-ordinating the functions of the provincial administration and its departments”.
en.interpretation:
The powers and functions of the Premier is specifically provided for in section 127 of the Constitution which includes the assenting and signing of Bills and the appointment of commissions of inquiry within the province. Importantly, the provincial executive must act in accordance with the Constitution and the provincial constitution, if one has been passed. The province of the Western Cape passed a provincial constitution.

An important and unique mechanism for provincial interference in local government is provided for in section 139 of the Constitution. This section provides for interference by the provincial executive if a municipality is not adhering to its executive duties in terms of the Constitution. The provincial executive has the authority to take “any appropriate steps”. If the provincial executive authority does not or cannot fulfil this duty in terms of section 139, then the national executive authority must intervene.

en.title: Local Government
en.snippet: Deals with local government, consisting of municipalities which are vested with both legislative and executive authority.
en.topic_meaning: Chapter 7 of the Constitution deals with local government, consisting of municipalities which are vested with both legislative and executive authority. These are original powers which are derived directly from the Constitution. Section 151(3) of the Constitution emphasises that a municipality “has the right to govern, on its own initiative, the local government affairs of its community, subject to national and provincial legislation” and importantly national and provincial government may not “compromise or impede a municipality’s ability or right to exercise its power or perform its functions”.
en.interpretation: Municipalities have the power to pass laws in respect of the functional areas listed in Part B of Schedule 4 and Part B of Schedule 5. The Constitution also gives municipalities the right to exercise any power concerning a matter reasonably necessary for or incidental to the performance of its functions (found in Part B of Schedule 4 and Part B of Schedule 5).
en.mechanism: Different categories of municipalities are provided for in section 155 of the Constitution.
en.legislation: The Local Government: Municipal Structures Act 117 of 1998 further defines the different municipalities relating to categories and types of municipality. The Local Government: Municipal Systems Act 32 of 2000 provides for the manner in which municipal powers and functions are exercised.

en.title: Chapter 9 Institutions
en.snippet: Provides for the establishment of independent State institutions strengthening constitutional democracy.
en.topic_meaning: Chapter 9 of the Constitution provides for the establishment of independent State institutions strengthening constitutional democracy. These include the Public Protector; the South African Human Rights Commission; the Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural Religious and Linguistic Communities; the Commission for Gender Equality; the Auditor-General and the Electoral Commission and the Independent Broadcasting Authority. These institutions are often colloquially referred to as the “Chapter 9 institutions”.
en.interpretation:
These institutions in terms of section 181 of the Constitution are independent and are “subject only to the Constitution and the law”. It is critical to emphasise this provision. The Constitutional Court has emphasised that the Public Protector in fulfilling her mandate is “not supposed to bow down to anybody, not even at the door of the highest chambers of raw State power”.

These institutions are obligated in terms of section 181(2) of the Constitution to be impartial and to “exercise their functions without fear, favour or prejudice” and no “person or organ of state may interfere with the functioning of these institutions.” It is also important to note that these institutions only account to the National Assembly on their activities and performance. The remaining provisions of Chapter 9 of the Constitution provides for the functions of each of these institutions, their tenure and removal from office.
en.mechanism: The Public Protector and Auditor-General in specific are watchdogs over the State and are critical in the fight against corruption and enforcing accountability. The South African Human Rights Commission is mandated to monitor the observance of human rights and take action where human rights have been violated. The Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities has various powers including investigating matters concerning the rights of cultural, religious communities and the Commission for Gender Equality also has extensive power including the power to lobby and investigate issues relating to gender equality. The Electoral Commission is mandated to manage the elections of the national, provincial and municipal legislative bodies.

en.title: Public Procurement
en.snippet: Stipulates the constitutional standards of public procurement in South Africa.
en.topic_meaning:
Section 217 of the Constitution stipulates the constitutional standards of public procurement in South Africa.

Section 217(1) of the Constitution provides that:

“When an organ of state in the national, provincial or local sphere of government, or any other institution identified in national legislation, contracts for goods and services, it must do so in accordance with a system which is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost-effective.”

These five constitutional principles inform the law of public procurement in South Africa.

The Constitution also enables public procurement to be used as a tool to advance persons or categories of persons disadvantaged by unfair discrimination. Importantly, section 217(2) of the Constitution stipulates that the five constitutional principles identified in section 217(1) does not prohibit organs of State from implementing a procurement policy providing preferential allocation of contracts and advancing persons disadvantaged by unfair discrimination.
en.mechanism:
Section 217(3) of the Constitution requires national legislation to be enacted to provide a framework for such policy and the Preferential Procurement Policy Framework Act 5 of 2000 was specifically enacted in this regard.

Various laws give effect to these constitutional standards in section 217(1) of the Constitution such as the Public Finance Management Act 1 of 1999, which requires the National Treasury to determine a “framework for an appropriate procurement and provisioning system which is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost-effective”.

en.title: Legislative Process/Competence
en.snippet: The Constitution divides legislative power between various spheres of government, namely national (Parliament), provincial and local government.
en.topic_meaning: The Constitution divides legislative power between various spheres of government, namely national (Parliament), provincial and local government. The legislative authority of the national sphere of government is set out in section 44 of the Constitution; section 104 of the Constitution for the provincial sphere; and the powers and functions of municipalities can be found in section 156 of the Constitution. The three spheres of government do not compete with each other but should be viewed as working together and sharing responsibilities.
en.mechanism:
Importantly Schedule 4 of the Constitution stipulates functional areas of concurrent national and provincial legislative competence and this includes housing, health services and education (excluding tertiary education). This means that both the national and provincial governments can legislate on these areas. Part B of Schedule 4, stipulates functional areas in terms of which local government has concurrent legislative authority in order to manage their own affairs, such as municipal health services.

Schedule 5 of the Constitution stipulates functional areas in terms of which the provincial legislative authority has exclusive provincial competence, such as liquor licences and ambulance services. This means that the provincial government has exclusive legislative authority over these areas and the national government may only intervene and pass legislation on these functional areas in very limited circumstances. Part B of Schedule 5 also stipulates functional areas in terms of which local government has exclusive legislative competence in order to manage their affairs such as beaches and amusement facilities and the control of public nuisances.

en.title: Separation of Powers
en.snippet: This principle sees State power divided between the legislative branch, the executive branch and the judiciary.
en.topic_meaning: South Africa’s new constitutional order provides for a clear distinction between the three branches of the government in order to limit an over-concentration of State power in any one branch and to recognise the functional independence of the three branches of government. This doctrine of separation of powers sees State power divided between the legislative branch (which drafts the law), the executive branch (which implements the law) and the judiciary (which interprets and resolves dispute of the law). This doctrine allows for checks and balances to be carried out by each branch over the others, and ensures that no branch of government can usurp the power of another. Although not specifically mentioned in the Constitution, the doctrine of separation of powers is an essential component of the foundation of South African constitutional law.
en.interpretation: It should be noted that separation of powers is not an absolute principle. Thus, there is not a complete divide between the three branches of government and there is often an overlap. For example, in cases where Parliament has enacted legislation which the courts declare not to be in line with the Constitution, Parliament will be ordered to redraft the relevant parts of the legislation.

xh.title: Icandelo 1: IRiphablikhi yoMzantsi-Afrika
xh.snippet: Iziseko zoMgaqo-siseko
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 1 loMgaqo-siseko lichaza iziseko eyakhelwe phezu kwazo iRiphabliki YoMzantsi Afrika. Ligxininisa ulawulo loRhulumente wentando yesininzi kwaye liqinisekisa ukuba kwahlukwene nenkqubo yoCalulo apho uRhulumente wayenegunya elingalinganamida.

Liqinisekisa ukuba iRiphabliki yoMzantsi Afrika “ililizwe elinye, elizimeleyo, lentando yesininzi”. Esi siqinisekisa sisodwa sibalulekile kuba ngaphambi kowe-1994 uMzantsi Afrika wawahlulwe waba ngoorhulumente bamaphandle abahlukeneyo (iiBantustan) apho Abemi BoMzantsi Afrika Abantsundu babenziwa bangabemi. Icandelo 1 liqinisekisa nokuba iRiphabliki YoMzantsi Afrika yakhelwe kwiziseko ezinjengesidima sokuba ngumntu, ukungacaluli ngokwebala, ukulawula komthetho nokongama koMgaqo-siseko (nto leyo ethetha ukuba umthetho osungulwe nguMgaqo-siseko usebenza kubo bonke abantu kwaye ngowona mthetho mkhulu elizweni) kunye nenkqubo yolawulo lwesininzi evumela amaqela ezopolitiko aliqela.

Kubalulekile ukuphawula ukuba ukuhlaziywa kwecandelo 1 loMgaqo-siseko kufuna ukuba kufikelelwe inani eliphezulu labakuxhasayo. Ubuncinane kufuneka ama-75 pesenti amalungu ePalamente Yelizwe axhase olo hlaziyo kwaye kubekho ubuncinane inkxaso yamaphondo amathandathu kwiBhunga Lamaphondo Elizwe. Ngoko kusoloko kubalulekile ukubuza enoba nakuphi na ukuhlaziywa koMgaqo-siseko kuzichaphazela ngokungangqalanga na iziseko ezikwicandelo1 loMgaqo-siseko.
xh.interpretation: UMgaqo-siseko awumeli nje imiyalelo, iinkqubo ezilandelwayo nezakhiwo zenkqubo yentando yesininzi eMzantsi Afrika, ukwaqhubela phambili imilinganiselo neziseko uluntu oluzibona zifanelekile. Xa iinkundla zihlola enoba umthetho “uyahambisana na nomgaqo-siseko”, oko kukuthi, uyavunyelwa na nguMgaqo-siseko, ziye ziqwalasele neziseko ezikwicandelo 1, ngokukodwa ukuhambisana kwalo nokulawula komthetho.

xh.title: Icandelo 2: Ukongama koMgaqo-siseko
xh.snippet: Lo Mgaqo-siseko ungumthetho owongamileyo weRiphabliki.
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 2 loMgaqo-siseko elaziwa ngokuba lisolotya lokongama, liyinxalenye yeziseko zolawulo olutsha lomgaqo-siseko waseMzantsi Afrika. Liqinisekisa ukuba uMgaqo-siseko ungumthetho owongamileyo welizwe; ukuba kukho nawuphi na umthetho (enoba ngumthetho owisiweyo, ngumthetho oqhelekileyo okanye ngumthetho wesithethe) ongqubana nawo, kuya kulandelwa oko kuthethwa nguMgaqo-siseko.

Eli candelo liphinda liqinisekise ukuba kohlukenwe nengcamango yokuba yipalamente eyeyona yongamileyo. Phantsi kwengcamango ethi yipalamente eyongamileyo, iPalamente yayinegunya lokuwisa nawuphi na umthetho efuna ukuwuwisa ibe inkundla yayikwazi ukubhengeza loo mthetho njengongasebenziyo kuphela phantsi kweemeko ezithile ezinemiqathango emininzi. Ebudeni bexesha localulo, kwakusebenza ukongama kwepalamente eMzantsi Afrika. Ngenxa yoko imithetho epasiswe yiPalamente yayijonga izinto ezifunwa ligcuntswana labamhlophe kuphela ize ingawananzi amalungelo oluntu abo bonke abantu beminye imibala. IiNkundla zazingakwazi ukubhengeza uMthetho WasePalamente njengongasebenziyo kuba unyhasha amalungelo oluntu ibe zazikwazi ukubhengeza uMthetho njengongasebenziyo kuphela xa kukho iziphene kwinkqubo elandelwayo.
xh.interpretation: Phantsi kwengcamango ethi ngumgaqo-siseko owongamileyo, yonke imithetho imele ihambisane noMgaqo-siseko kunye noMqulu Wamalungelo okuMgaqo-siseko. Ngoku iinkundla ziyakwazi ukubhengeza umthetho nezenzo njengezingasebenziyo ukuba azihambisani noko kuthethwa nguMgaqo-siseko.

xh.title: Icandelo 3: Ubumi
xh.snippet: Izinto ezenza abantu baseMzantsi Afrika babe ngabemi.
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 3 loMgaqo-siseko lithi uMzantsi Afrika unabemi kwaye bonke abemi boMzantsi Afrika abaneli nje ukuba nemfanelo “ngokulinganayo yokuxhamla kumalungelo, kwiinyhweba neenzuzo zokuba ngummi” kodwa ngokulinganayo “banoxanduva lokufeza iimbopheleleko noxanduva lokuba ngummi”.

Phantsi kwenkqubo yomgaqo-siseko entsha yoMzantsi Afrika, ilungelo lokuba ngummi kuMgaqo-siseko lisekelwe ekuqondeni ukuba bonke abantu bayalingana. Ilungelo lokuba ngummi livumela umntu ukuba afumane amalungelo ahlukeneyo anjengelungelo lokumelwa kwezopolitiko nenkululeko yokuhambahamba neyokuhlala.
xh.interpretation: Kubalulekile ukuqonda ukuba iNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko iye yangqina kumatyeli ahlukeneyo umahluko ongayondelelananga phakathi kwabemi nabantu abangengobemi awuhambisani noMgaqo-siseko nokuba isininzi samalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo sinikwa bonke abantu.
xh.legislation: The State is obliged to enact national legislation to define citizenship and the South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 provides for how one can acquire, lose and regain South African citizenship. The recognition of the right to citizenship as a founding provision in the Constitution must be understood in its historical context. During apartheid, black South Africans were not recognised as citizens of South Africa and were made citizens of defined territories (known as Homelands) under the Bantu Homelands Citizenship Act 26 of 1970.

xh.title: Icandelo 4: Umhobe Wesizwe
xh.snippet: Kuchazwa inkqubo edibene nomhobe wesizwe woMzantsi Afrika.
xh.topic_meaning:
Ukuza kuthi ga ngowe-1994, umhobe wesizwe osemthethweni eMzantsi Afrika yayingu-Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, owawusekelwe kumbongo owabhalwa ngowe-1918 ngu-CJ Langenhoven. Ngowe-1994, owayesakuba nguMongameli uNelson Mandela wenza isaziso sokuba ukongezelela ku-Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, noNkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika wayeza kuba ngumhobe wesizwe. UNkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika ekuqaleni wayeliculo lecawa kodwa kamva waye wayanyaniswa neAfrican National Congress waza waculwa kakhulu xa kuqhankqalazwa nxamnye norhulumente wocalulo. Ngowe-1997, Owayesakuba NguMongameli uNelson Mandela wabhengeza umhobe wesizwe omtsha waseMzantsi Afrika, owawuluhlelo oludityanisiweyo luka-“Nkosi Sikelel iAfrika” no-“Die Stem van Suid-Afrika” (“Isimemelelo SoMzantsi Afrika”).

Umhobe wesizwe ubonisa ukuzibophelela ekungcibeni iintanda zexesha elidluleyo ngokweNtshayelelo YoMgaqo-siseko kwaye ubonisa ukumanyana kwabantu nangona bengafani.

xh.title: Icandelo 5: Iflegi yesizwe
xh.snippet: Kuchazwa inkqubo edibene neflegi yoMzantsi Afrika.
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 5 loMgaqo-siseko lithi iflegi yeRiphabliki inombala omnyama, nagolide, naluhlaza, namhlophe, nabomvu, nablowu, ngendlela ochazwe ngayo kwiSahluko 1 soMgaqo-siseko. Iflegi yelizwe yadizayinwa ngowayesakuba nguMthunywa KaRhulumente WoMzantsi Afrika, uMnu Fred Brownwell. Iflegi yelizwe yasetyenziswa okokuqala ngowama-27 kuEpreli 1994 ibe idizayini eyintloko yale flegi, emile ngathi ngu-‘V’ odibanayo abe libhanti elinye ngokuhambisana neempapasho ezisemthethweni zikaRhulumente, ingatolikwa “njengokudibana kwabantu abangafaniyo boluntu loMzantsi Afrika, bethatha uhambo oluphambi kwabo ngomanyano”.

xh.title: Icandelo 6: Iilwimi
xh.snippet: Ukugqalwa kweelwimi zaseburhulumenteni zaseMzantsi Afrika.
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 5 loMgaqo-siseko ligqala iilwimi zaseburhulumenteni zeRiphabliki ngokuthi “sisiPedi, isiSuthu, isiTswana, isiSwati, isiVenda, isiTsonga, iAfrikansi, isiNgesi, isiNdebele, isiXhosa nesiZulu”. Eli candelo liphinda ligqale “imbali yokuncitshiswa kokusetyenziswa nokuthotywa kweelwimi zomthonyama” lize liyalele uRhulumente ukuba athathe “amanyathelo asebenzisekayo okuphakamisa nokuphuhlisa ukusetyenziswa kwezi lwimi”. Urhulumente kazwelonke nabamaphondo baphinda bayalelwe ukuba “balawule kwaye babeke esweni ukusebenzisa kwabo iilwimi zaseburhulumenteni” ngemithetho onangamanye amanyathelo nokuba zonke iilwimi zimele ziphathwe ngokulinganayo. 

Liqonda ukuba bekukho inkqubo yokunanzwa kwezinye iilwimi zomthonyama, icandelo 6(2) loMgaqo-siseko libeka imbopheleleko phezu kukaRhulumente yokuthatha amanyathelo asebenzisekayo okuphakamisa ezi lwimi. Ezinye iilwimi ezithethwa ligcuntswana eMzantsi Afrika, ezinjengesiHindi nesiGrike, azidweliswanga njengeelwimi zaseburhulumenteni. Isizathu kukuba zithethwa kwezinye iindawo zehlabathi ibe ukuqhubeka kwazo zikho akuxhomekekanga ekusetyenzisweni nasekukhuleni kwazo eMzantsi Afrika.

Icandelo 6(4) lifuna ukuba zonke iilwimi zaseburhulumenteni ziphathwe ngokulinganayo.
xh.mechanism: Icandelo 6 loMgaqo-siseko likwayalela ukuba kusungulwe iBhodi Yeelwimi YaseMzantsi Afrika ekufuneka ikhuthaze ize idale iimeko zokuphuhliswa nokusetyenziswa kwazo zonke iilwimi zaseburhulumenteni kunye nolwimi lwamaKhoi, olwamaNama nolwamaSan kunye nolwimi lwezandla. Ukugqalwa koLwimi Lwezandla LwaseMzantsi Afrika (South African Sign Language [“SASL”]) njengolwimi lwaseburhulumenteni lwe-12 kudala kuyinto etshis’ ibunzi ibe ngowama-2017, iKomiti Edibeneyo Yokuhlola Umgaqo-siseko yasePalamente (Parliament’s Joint Constitutional Review Committee) yacebisa ukuba i-SASL igqalwe njengolwimi lwaseburhulumenteni lwe-12 nto leyo eza kufuna ukuba kuhlaziywe umgaqo-siseko.
xh.legislation: The Use of Official Languages Act 12 of 2012 has been specifically enacted to give effect to the constitutional obligations in terms of section 6 of the Constitution. The National Language Policy Framework was adopted in 2002 by Cabinet. Some of the aims of this policy are to promote the equitable use of the 11 official languages and to ensure redress for previously marginalised official languages.

xh.title: Icandelo 7: Amalungelo
xh.snippet: UMqulu Wamalungelo “ulilitye lembombo lentando yesininzi eMzantsi Afrika”.
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 7 loMgaqo-siseko lithi uMqulu Wamalungelo “ulilitye lembombo lentando yesininzi eMzantsi Afrika” kwaye uMqulu Wamalungelo “uqulethe amalungelo abo bonke abantu elizweni lethu kwaye uqinisekisa isidima sokuba ngumntu, ukulingana nenkululeko yentando yesininzi.”
xh.interpretation: Icandelo 7 lithwalisa uRhulumente imbopheleleko yokuhlonela, ukukhusela, ukukhuthaza nokufezekisa amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo. Ngenxa yoko, uRhulumente akufuneki nje aphephe ukuphazamisana namalungelo abanye abantu, kodwa ukwanembopheleleko yokukhusela nokukhuthaza la malungelo. Imbopheleleko yokuhlonela ifuna ukuba uRhulumente angaphazamisani nokufunyanwa kwalo malungelo. Imbopheleleko yokukhusela ifuna uRhulumente akhusele nxamnye nabani na ophazamisana nelungelo lomnye umntu. Imbopheleleko yokukhuthaza ngamanye amaxesha ichazwa njengembopheleleko yokwazisa abantu ngamalungelo ngeeprogramu zokubafundisa. Imbopheleleko yokufezekisa ifuna uRhulumente enze okuthile kwaye athathe amanyathelo okuwisa imithetho, olawulo, oqingqo-mali, eenkundla, okukhuthaza namanye amanyathelo ukuze abantu abangawafumani nabangawafikeleli ngokupheleleyo ngoku amalungelo abo bakwazi ukuwafikelela.
xh.mechanism: Amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo asenokusikelwa umda kuxhomekeka ekubeni oko kusikelwa umda kuhlangabezana noko kufunwa luvavanyo olukwicandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko. Amanye amalungelo ayachaza kwawona ukuba axhomekeke entonini, ngokomzekelo njengelungelo lokuba nendlu. Kodwa ke, kubalulekile nakuphi na ukusikelwa umda kwelungelo elikuMqulu Wamalugelo kumele kuvavanywe nxamnye necandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko ukuze kugqitywe enoba siyavakala na isizathu sokuba lisikelwe umda okanye ngaba kuyavunyelwa na ngumgaqo-siseko.

xh.title: Icandelo 8: Ukusebenza koMqulu
xh.snippet: Kuxutyushwa ngabantu osebenza kubo uMqulu Wamalungelo.
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 8 loMgaqo-siseko lithi uMqulu Wamalungelo, iSahluko 2 soMgaqo-siseko, “usebenza kuwo wonke umthetho, kwaye unkqamangela abawisi-mthetho, urhulumente, iinkundla nawo onke amacandelo karhulumente.” Okubalulekileyo kukuba, uMqulu Wamalungelo ubeka imbopheleleko hayi kuRhulumente kuphela kodwa nakubantu kunye neenkampani, ngokomkhamo osebenzayo xa kujongwa “uhlobo lwelungelo nohlobo lwembopheleleko ebekiweyo”. Oku kuqukwa kwazo kubonisa ukuba iyaqondwa into yokuba kwezinye iimeko abantu kunye neenkampani ezingenguye uRhulumente, kungenzeka zibe negunya elikhulu kakhulu zize zinyhashe amalungelo abanye abantu.
xh.interpretation: Amanye amalungelo akumgaqo-siseko anjengelungelo lokuba neemfihlelo anokunyanzeliswa phakathi kwabantu. Phakathi kwabantu kukho imbopheleleko yokuphumeza okulungileyo. Olu hlobo lokusetyenziswa koMqulu Wamalungelo lwaziwa ngokuba lusetyenziso oluya emacaleni loMqulu Wamalungelo. Xa uMqulu Wamalungelo usetyenziswa ukuya ecaleni, awuniki nje abantu amalungelo, kodwa ubanika nembopheleleko yokuhlonela amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo, ubuncinane kwiimeko ezithile. Ngamanye amazwi, xa uMqulu Wamalungelo usetyenziswa ukuya ecaleni, kokubini uRhulumente nabantu bayabotshelelwa nguMqulu Wamalungelo.
xh.mechanism: Ngokomzekelo, uRhulumente kufueka aqiniseke ukuba bonke abemi banelungelo olokuvota kunyulo ibe le yimbopheleleko ebekwa ngumgaqo-siseko enokufezekiswa nguRhulumente kuphela. URhulumente akanakuvimba ummi eli lungelo. Le ndlela yokusetyenziswa koMqulu Wamalungelo yaziwa ngokuba lusetyenziso olunyukayo loMqulu Wamalungelo oluthetha ngokukhuselwa komntu kwigunya likaRhulumente. Xa uMqulu Wamalungelo usetyenziswa ngokunyukayo, unika umntu ilungelo uze ubeke imbopheleleko kuRhulumente yokuhlonela, ukukhusela, ukukhuthaza nokufezekisa amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo.

xh.title: Icandelo 9: Ukulingana
xh.snippet: Kucaciswa ilungelo lokulingana kwabo bonke abantu.
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 9 loMgaqo-siseko likhusela ilungelo lokulingana kwabantu. Icandelo 9(1) “lithi bonke abantu bayalingana phambi komthetho kwaye banelungelo lokukhuselwa ngumthetho nokuzuza ngokulinganayo kuwo”. Icandelo 9(2) lithetha ngamanyathelo okulungisa amele athathwe ukuze kuncedwe amaqela aye acalulwa ngokungafanelekanga kwixesha elidluleyo. Ukongezelela koko, icandelo 9(3) liyakwalela ukucalulwa ngokungafanelekanga okusekelwe kwizinto ezifana nebala, utyekelo lwesondo, ubuni neenkolelo. Olu ludwe lwezinto abantu abanokucalulwa ngazo aluphelelanga. URhulumente unembopheleleko yokuqulunqa imithetho namanye amanyathelo okukhusela nokuqhubela phambili iintlobo ezithile zabantu abebehlelelekile ngaphambili.
xh.interpretation: Isiqinisekiso esikumgaqo-siseko selungelo lokulingana sixhaswa yingcamango yokulingana ngokoqobo. Imbono eqhelekileyo yokulingana ngokusemthethweni ifuna ukuba abantu baphathwe ngendlela efanayo kungakhathaliseki ukuba zinjani na iimeko zabo. Kodwa ke, ukuphathwa ngendlela efanayo kuphela akwanelanga ukuze uluntu lulingane ngendlela efunwa nguMgaqo-siseko. Ukulingana ngokoqobo kujolisa ekuphumezeni iziphumo ezilinganayo hayi ukuphathwa ngendlela elinganayo. Imiqobo abajongana nayo abantu, enjengembali yokucalulwa ngendlela engafanelekanga, ethintela ukulingana kweziphumo iyaqwalaselwa. Ukulingana okuqhelekileyo akuyiqwalaseli into yokuba ifuthe lentlalo, loqoqosho nelokudlelw’ indlala kwixesha elidluleyo liyahluka kubantu ngabantu nokuba amanyathelo okuzama ukudala ukulingana alungisa ezi zinto zikhoyo. Kungokulungisa ezi zinto zikhoyo kuphela apho kuya kufikelelwa ekubeni kulinganwe.
xh.legislation: The Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act 4 of 2000 is the constitutionally mandated legislation adopted pursuant to section 9(4) of the Constitution to give effect to the constitutional prohibition against unfair discrimination.

xh.title: Icandelo 10 : Isidima somntu
xh.snippet: Kugqalwa into yokuba wonke umntu unelungelo lesidima esingenakohluthwa.
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 10 loMgaqo-siseko ligqala into yokuba wonke umntu “unelungelo lesidima esingenakohluthwa nelungelo lokuba sihlonitshwe isidima sakhe kwaye sikhuselwe”. Le nto ithetha ukuba ilungelo lomntu lokuba nesidima ulifumana nje kuba engumntu. Ilungelo lesidima alisosiseko nje kuphela esikwicandelo 1 loMgaqo-siseko, kodwa likwalilungelo elahlukileyo, nelinokunyanzeliswa lilodwa.
xh.interpretation:
Isidima kunzima ukusichaza, kodwa sibandakanya ukuqonda ixabiso analo umntu ngamnye. Ngokuyintloko, ilungelo lesidima lifumaneka ngokuzenzekelayo ngenxa yokuba ungumntu. Undoqo wesidima kukuthatha bonke abantu njengabanexabiso elingenakulinganiswa nanto, kungakhathaliseki ukuba zinjani na iimeko zabo, ibe bafanele baphathwe ngolo hlobo ke.

Ilungelo lesidima libeka isiseko kwaye linceda ekutolikweni kwamalungelo amaninzi akuMqulu Wamalungelo. Ngenxa yale nto, ilungelo lesidima alidli ngakuvela xa kuxoxwa amatyala apho amalungelo omntu eye anyhashwa, ngaphandle kwaxa lingekho elinye ilungelo elikuMqulu Wamalungelo elikhusela okanye eliphumeza oko kufunwayo. Xa kunjalo, ilungelo lesidima lingasetyenziswa ziinkundla ukulungisa ukunyhashwa kwamalungelo omntu angenakulungiswa ngokusebenzisa amanye amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo. Eli lungelo liphinda linxibelelane nengcamango yentando yesininzi kwaye ligqala into yokuba abantu banelungelo nenkululeko yokuzenzela ukhetho.

xh.title: Ubomi
xh.snippet: Liqinisekisa wonke umntu ngelungelo lokuphila.
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 11 loMgaqo-siseko liqinisekisa wonke umntu ngelungelo lokuphila kwaye lilungelo elingaziwa kwiimeko ezithile. Kubalulekile ukuba uqonde ukuba nangona ilungelo lokuphila lingaxhomekeka kwimeko yokujonga i-alinakusikelwa umda ngokufanelekileyo (ukuba kukho isizathu soko kusikelwa umda) ngokwecandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko, elithetha ngokusikelwa umda kwamalungelo kuMgaqo-siseko.
xh.interpretation: Ukuhambisana nomgaqo-siseko kwesigwebo sithunyelweambo sesinye sezigwebo ezibalaseleyo zokuqala zeNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko ibe nangona isigwebo sesininzi sasingajoliswanga kwilungelo lobomi, ngokuqinisekileyo izigwebo ezivumelana naso zagxininisa ukuba ilungelo lokuphila neleselene nelungelo lesidima. Iijaji ezininzi zokuphawula ukuba isigwebo sentambo sasinganeli ngaphandle ukusikela umda ilungelo lokuphila, kodwa sasilishenxisa ngokupheleleyo. Okubalulekileyo kukuba ilungelo lokuphila lachazwa njengelungelo lokuba nexesha lokubonisa ukuxabana nokubaluleka komntu ngamnye eluntwini.
